ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

FIRST-TIME HDB FLAT BUYERS

(Number not taking HDB concessionary loans)

     1.  Mr Zainudin Nordin asked the Minister for National Development (a) from 2003 to date, how many Singaporeans who are first-time buyers of HDB flats did not use the subsidised loan scheme from HDB; (b) how many of these buyers faced difficulties in servicing the bank origination loan; and (c) what are the

Column: 1175

alternatives for these buyers apart from letting the bank repossess their flats.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman) (for the Minister for National Development):  Mr Speaker, Sir, HDB records show that from 2003 to June 2007, there are about 11,500 first-time buyers of HDB flats who chose not to take a concessionary loan from HDB, but instead opted for a mortgage loan from commercial banks at market interest rates.

 

     About 3%, or 320, of these cases faced difficulties in servicing their bank loans and had to give up their flats in mortgagee sales.  Flat buyers who take bank loans to finance their flats are informed that they would be subject to the mortgage financing policies of the banks.  Banks have their own financial assistance measures.  Mortgagors who have problems servicing their bank loans should approach their banks for help. 

 

     For the 320 cases whose flats were repossessed by the banks, they have generally been able to find alternative accommodation on their own.  In a small number of cases, about 30, HDB has acceded to their appeals to be allocated a HDB rental flat, in view of their extenuating circumstances.

     Mr Zainudin Nordin (Bishan-Toa Payoh):  Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary mentioned about "informed".  How are the mortgagees informed about their commitment and the help that they can get?  And why are these first-time buyers going to the bank rather than getting their loans from the HDB?

     Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman:  Sir, the Member is very right.  We want to make sure that home buyers purchase their flats with relevant information, ie, that they

Column: 1176

make informed decisions, before they commit to the purchase of their flats.  Information is available everywhere - on their websites, in their promotional brochures, and in a lot of documents that are made available to the flat buyers.  What is important is to make sure that flat buyers seek relevant information from these relevant sources.

 

     Apart from that, many flat buyers rely on their housing agents to help them with flat purchases.  One of the most important things is to make sure that housing agents also play their role in informing their clients with regard to information that is relevant to them, whether they are eligible for loans and grants, and so on.  What is important is for the flat buyers, apart from getting all this information, to make informed decisions with regard to what they are capable of buying.  We always encourage financial prudence to make sure that they buy within their means.

 

     HDB has also put in place several measures.  So when flat buyers first come in, at the point of first appointment, HDB officers will look through a checklist and make sure that flat buyers are aware of their eligibility and that they are informed of what are their eligibility as far as loans are concerned.

 

     With regard to why they choose bank loans, it is market forces, independent of what they choose to take up.  At some point, the market rates given by the banks are a lot more attractive.  So we leave it to the flat buyers to make the decision, so long as we make sure that they have made their decisions with the relevant information that is being given to them.

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines):  I would like to ask the Parliamentary Secretary, for flat buyers who go for bank loans but then find that they cannot service them, can HDB allow them to switch to HDB concessionary loans?

Column: 1177

     Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman:  Sir, HDB cannot do that.  It is not wise for HDB to do that.  HDB cannot be the one to take over all the loans that are not well serviced by the banks.  The most important lesson for flat buyers is to make sure that they understand the commitment that they have made with the banks.  They are aware as to what are the obligations they have when they take on the bank loans.  Like I mentioned in my earlier reply, the banks have got their own financial assistance measures.  They should go back to the banks and try to get assistance from the banks.  As far as possible, HDB will try to help those who are really in financial difficulties.  Sometimes, we assist them.  We waive the minimum occupation period for them to sell their flat to resolve some of their issues.  But at the end of the day, it is not wise for HDB to take over loans that are not well serviced by the banks.

     Mr Zainudin Nordin:  If after they have sold their flat they want to buy another flat and take a loan from HDB, would they be considered as a first-time loan mortgagee by the HDB?

&nbs2/16/2013p;    Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman:  If the first loan that they have taken is from the bank and they have been assessed as not having taken any loans before, then the household would be considered to be a first-time loan applicant and, therefore, they would be eligible for a HDB loan.  But we have to really assess the case.  This is because sometimes we have situations where the husbands or wives may have taken first loans with flats that they owned with their parents and they are not aware of it, and they think that they are first-time buyers.  They come back to us and HDB made an assessment that when they had taken the first loan with their parents, they would be considered as second-time applicants and they would not be eligible for another loan unless they are an upgrader.

Column: 1178

     Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng (West Coast):  Sir, may I ask the Parliamentary Secretary about the logic of allowing second HDB loans to upgraders and not for downgraders.  The latter group is apparently  the more needy group.

     Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman:  Sir, I think we have discussed this policy before.  By and large, the assumption behind the policy is one where we want to encourage upgraders.  So, first-time buyers are eligible for a concessionary loan and, as they improve their lives, we want to encourage them to upgrade, and therefore we facilitate their upgrading with another concessionary loan.  However, we understand that downgraders may require certain assistance.  But not all downgraders require financial assistance.  This is because sometimes when they monetise or sell their assets, they do make sufficient proceeds, and we believe that the proceeds are sufficient for them to purchase a smaller flat.  For cases that require assistance, HDB will look at them on a case-by-case basis.  But we want to discourage people from downgrading, making proceeds from the downgrading, and then getting another concessionary loan, because these are subsidised loans from the Government.

Column: 1178

PURCHASE OF HDB FLATS

(Assistance in obtaining housing loans)

     2.  Dr Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim asked the Minister for National Development what action has been taken to assist Singaporeans who are unable to obtain housing loans from commercial banks in the purchase of HDB flats.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien) (for the Minister for National Development):  Mr Speaker, Sir, since 1st January 2003, flat buyers who do not qualify for HDB concessionary loans can apply for a mortgage loan at commercial interest

Column: 1179

rates from the banks or financial institutions.  Those who do not qualify for concessionary loans include private property owners, high-income households, non-citizen households, those who have previously taken two HDB loans, as well as those who have already enjoyed one concessionary loan and are not upgrading in their current flat purchase. 

   

     There is a wide variety of commercial loan packages available in the market.  Generally, HDB flat buyers who have a stable household income and are buying a flat within their means should be able to secure a bank loan to finance their flat purchase. 
 
     However, there is a small group of flat buyers who are unable to secure a bank loan for various reasons, even though they may have the financial means to service a mortgage at commercial rates.  They include those with poor credit histories or are undischarged bankrupts.  To help meet the needs of this group of flat buyers, HDB has recently implemented an assistance measure to provide them with mortgage loans at commercial interest rates.  As with other HDB loans, credit assessment will be applied to ensure financial prudence on the part of the flat buyer. 

 

     I want to clarify and emphasise that HDB is not re-introducing market rate loans as a mortgage financing option for flat buyers.  This is a limited assistance measure extended to a select group of buyers who face difficulty in obtaining a bank loan to finance their flat purchase.  HDB will assess appeals for these loans on a case-by-case basis, and we reserve the right to reject cases that do not meet our guidelines.

     Dr Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim (Marine Parade):  Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to thank the MOS for giving a good answer. 

Column: 1180

May I know how long does the HDB take to process an appeal for a HDB loan from a resident who is unable to obtain a housing loan from a commercial bank?  This is because sometimes during my meet-the-people session, I meet residents who are concerned that they are unable to obtain HDB loans for the purchase of their next flat when they are not able to obtain a commercial loan.  For some, their current flat is going to be repossessed by the commercial banks and they have enjoyed the allocated number of subsidy.

     Mr Speaker:  No speeches, Dr Faishal. 

     Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien:  Mr Speaker, I would like to thank Dr Faishal for the supplementary question. 

 

     HDB will expedite such appeal cases.  But, fundamentally, we would like, as much as possible, to encourage these buyers to explore the commercial market first.  As I have clarified, it is not HDB's intention to re-enter this market with a loan at market rate.  We are only there to help very exceptional cases and, in most cases, we have to be thoroughly assessing the situation and we have to satisfy ourselves that indeed they do not have any access to the bank market before we grant a loan.  Concessionary rate loans are heavily subsidised, especially if we think about it over the loan period.  Therefore, we view these as a subsidy.  For us to offer another loan at market rate is really just to help the very few cases who we think genuinely have problems with access to bank market to find financing for their home. 

     Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng:  Sir, to the Minister of State, I can well understand why HDB wants to reduce its role as a financier and concentrate on its role as a developer.  For the resources available to finance HDB flat purchases, would it not be more logical to channel them to downgraders who actually need them?  Many downgraders who are facing

Column: 1181

financial difficulties wish to downgrade, which is a policy I think we would encourage, because this is financial prudence.  Yet, they are unable to get bank loans.  So, basically, they are stuck.  Can the Ministry review that policy?

     Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien:  When we look at this assistance measure that we are putting in place, we are really looking at a very small subset of the applicants.  Not all downgraders are not given access to financial market.  Many of them, despite the need to downgrade, can access the bank loan market and, therefore, should do so.  I would say that what we are doing now is to limit to a very small subset that not only could be looking at downgrading as an option but, because of their past problems - it could be bad credit histories or that they may be involved in litigation - that has basically barred them from accessing the commercial loan market.  So this is really a small subset.  I agree with the hon. Member that we have, in a way, to apply our subsidy very judiciously and, therefore, we are looking at a smaller subset that Mr Cedric Foo has mentioned.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir):  Sir, banks require buyers to pay the first 5% in cash.  Can this requirement be waived?

     Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien:  Mr Speaker, Sir, I believe this question is much better channelled to the banks.  But since they are not here, I think it is not a question that MND is privileged to answer.

 

 

Column: 1181

ADMISSION INTO LOCAL UNIVERSITIES

      3.  Mr Zaqy Mohamad asked the Minister for Education in light of local students not being able to gain admission to the three local universities despite the increase in the number of places (a) whether he will provide an update on the recent admission exercise for local universities; and (b) what measures are taken by his Ministry to ensure that local A-level and polytechnic students have

Column: 1182

sufficient places for accredited tertiary education in Singapore.

      4. Mr Zainudin Nordin asked the Minister for Education (a) whether our local universities are producing enough graduates to meet the needs of our industries; (b) what is the average growth in the number of local university places in the last ten years; (c) whether local universities are able to cope with the increase in intake; and (d) whether the local universities' vision to have more international students is being achieved at the expense of local students.

     The Minister of State for Education (Mr Gan Kim Yong) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, may I have your permission to take both Questions No. 3 and 4 together?

    Mr Speaker:  Yes.

      Mr Gan Kim Yong:  Sir, we have increased the number of university places over the years.  The number of places at NUS, NTU and SMU together has increased by an average of about 5% each year over the past 10 years.  The proportion of each cohort of local students entering the three universities will increase to about 23.5% this year, compared to 20.8% in 2000 and 15% in 1990.

 

     In addition, MOE is encouraging the polytechnics to link up with Foreign Specialised Institutions to offer degree programmes in niche disciplines.  For example, Ngee Ann Polytechnic has tied up with Wheelock College from the US to offer a degree programme in early childhood education, for which Wheelock has a strong reputation.  These specialised degree programmes will provide our students with more opportunities to pursue university education.

 

    We are progressively moving towards the current target of providing subsidised

Column: 1183

university education for 25% of each cohort of local students.


     I would like to assure the House also that the local universities' vision to have more international students is not being achieved at the expense of local students.  University places for foreign students are over and above those that are set aside for local students. 

 

     International students play an important role. Their presence helps to create diversity in our campuses, gives them a more enriching learning experience and better prepares our students for the globalised future. 

 

     Turning to Mr Zaqy Mohamad's request for an update on the recent university admission exercise, the three universities will provide a total of 14,685 places for Academic Year 2007, compared to the intake of about 13,420 students last year.  This is an increase of about 1,270 places, or about 10%.  This increase is sufficient to cater to the larger cohort of  what we call 'Dragon' girls who will enter the universities this year.

 

     Each application, including every appeal, is carefully and fairly examined by the universities' admissions offices.  Each student is assessed on the basis of merit.

     Mr Zainudin Nordin:  Sir, though we understand the need to have international students, the perspective of students who have been rejected from entering the universities is that the places that are available could have been offered to the locals.  So how do we rationalise the same amount of resources provided for the university education to the foreign students?

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:  Mr Speaker, I am glad that the Member has accepted the need for international students' presence

Column: 1184

here to enrich the learning experience of our own local students because we are facing a rapidly globalised environment here.  It is also important for us to understand that each university has its own admission criteria and students who are able to meet the admission criteria would have been admitted into the universities because they operate on a very open merit-based system. Therefore, as we move towards our current target of 25% cohort participation, the universities will continue to look at additional places to accommodate our students to provide them with opportunities to pursue university education here.

     Mr Zaqy Mohamad (Hong Kah):  Sir, when do we expect to reach the 25% cohort participation of degree holders?  How do we compare this 25% cohort participation with respect to other mature economies?  Will the Government consider putting a second-tier tertiary education, for example, more state-funded universities to cater to the average students out of polytechnics and 'A' levels?

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:  Mr Speaker, I would like to thank the Member for the questions.  I think we have increased the university participation rate in gradual steps, not in large jumps, so as to maintain the quality of graduates from our universities here, and also to ensure that our graduates are readily employable.  Based on 2006 Graduate Employment Survey, it shows that 86% of graduates from our three universities were able to find full-time employment within six months of graduation.  It is therefore important that we continue to produce graduates who are employable, rather than jump into increasing the capacity of the universities.  In terms of participation rate, while our target participation rate is 25%, we also understand that many of our students who went through polytechnic education would continue to look for opportunities to upgrade and pursue university education.  It may not neces-

Column: 1185

sarily be immediately after their polytechnic diploma. Some of them would work for a few years and they would continue to upgrade.  Overall, we are looking at more than 40% of our population who would eventually pursue a degree programme.  This position compares quite favourably with many of the developed economies in the world. So we are also watching the progress of the other countries. We also need to be careful not to end up in a situation where many countries found themselves in when they expanded university participation too rapidly.

      Mr Siew Kum Hong (Nominated Member):  Sir, I have two supplementary questions. The first question is I would like to ask the MOS to clarify what he meant when he said that places for foreign students are over and above the places for local students. Does this mean that places are offered to foreign students only after all eligible local students have been offered and have accepted their places?  My second question is this. The MOS has mentioned that there are 14,000-odd places for year of admission 2007.  Out of these 14,000-plus places, how many places will be going to foreign students?

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:  Mr Speaker, let me just give the House some benchmark numbers so that we can have a feel.  During this year's admission exercise, a total of 28,000 local students applied to local universities.  Out of that, 14,000 (49%) were offered places. Similarly, about 23,000 foreign students applied to the universities for the same admission year and only 987 [Please see clarification during sitting on 27th August 2007.*] were given places, that is, 4.3% [Please see clarification during sitting on 27th August 2007.* ].  So on that basis, we want to demonstrate that the universities do give priority to our local students.  And for our students who can qualify, based on the requirements of each discipline or

Column: 1186

faculty, they would have been given admission.  Beyond that, the universities would want to ensure that there are also sufficient foreign students to provide diversity and it is part of the learning experience that we want our students to go through as well during their university education here.


*Col. 1347, 27th August 2007.

      Mr Liang Eng Hwa (Holland-Bukit Timah):  Sir, I would like to ask the MOS whether it is a healthy situation to have large numbers of deserving Singaporeans who are not able to make it to the local universities despite their good grades and having to make their own arrangements, at their own expense, for overseas education or a private degree.  Will that result in these Singaporeans being less rooted to Singapore?

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:  Mr Speaker, as I mentioned in my reply earlier, it is also important for us to look at the balance between employability, responding to the needs of the industry and, at the same time, to address the aspirations of our Singaporeans.  Many of them, even though they are not able to go into universities right from the onset, they do progress through the polytechnic route and, eventually, they look at the possibility of furthering their university education through the polytechnic route. As I mentioned in my reply, the polytechnics are also developing degree programmes in collaboration with specialised institutions that offer niche programmes that are in demand by the industry today in Singapore.  I think we provide many routes of advancement for our students to realise their aspirations and to allow them to pursue their education opportunities.

MASS RAPID TRANSIT DOWNTOWN LINE

(Expediting of construction)

     5. Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng asked the Minister for Transport if the construction

Column: 1187

of the MRT Downtown Line can be expedited.

      6. Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Minister for Transport (a) whether the Ministry will consider expediting the construction of the Bukit Timah corridor of the Downtown Line as 2015 is too long to wait for its completion; and (b) what are the criteria used in determining how the stations along this line will be located.

     The Minister for Transport (Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat):  Sir, with your permission, can I take Question Nos. 5 and 6 together as they are related?

     Mr Speaker:  Yes.

     Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat:  Sir, the Government is committed to ensuring the timely completion of the Downtown Line (DTL).

 

     The DTL is a 40-kilometres rail line that will connect the north-western and eastern areas of the island to the CBD and the Marina Bay area. It will be built in three stages. The first stage, or DTL 1, which serves the new developments in the Marina Bay, such as the Marina Bay Sands Integrated Resort and the new Marina Bay Financial Centre, is targeted for completion in 2013.  The second stage, serving the Bukit Timah corridor and Bukit Panjang area, is scheduled for completion in 2015.  The final stage, which serves areas such as Bedok Reservoir and Tampines, is expected to be completed in 2018.  By implementing the project in phases, commuters can enjoy the benefits of the DTL even before the entire line is completed.

 

     In working out the implementation schedule, LTA took into account the need to meet strategic transport needs and

Column: 1188

demand as well as economic and financial viability considerations. The scheduling of the project also took into account the scale and complexity of the project as well as the resources required to manage and execute the project safely. The DTL is the longest underground rail project to date and runs through built-up corridors.  LTA has already started preparatory work for the first two stages of DTL.

 

     As to how the locations of the stations are determined, LTA takes into consideration the need to maximise the stations' accessibility and connectivity to population and employment centres.  Where feasible, interchanges will be built to link the DTL with existing RTS lines, to connect the DTL to the rest of the RTS network. Engineering requirements and site conditions also affect station locations. LTA is still in the process of finalising the details of station locations.

      Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng:  Sir, I understand from the Minister that the DTL will take up to 2018 before final completion. In the interim, can I understand how the Ministry will provide new capacity, whether rail or bus, to cater to the growth in demand which is expected to be very strong in the next few years?

      Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat:  Sir, my Ministry, the Land Transport Authority (LTA) and the Public Transport Council (PTC), on an on-going basis, monitors the traffic conditions in our public transport system, in terms of crowding and capacity.  Where necessary, the PTC and the LTA will work closely with the public transport operators to increase bus capacity. The Member pointed out that it takes up to 2018 to build a rail line, so what happens in the meantime. So where necessary, in a particular area, where it is getting very congested, we look towards increasing bus capacity. This could be in terms of increasing bus service frequencies or new bus routes, ie, new buses coming on stream.

Column: 1189

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong):  Sir, we heard the Minister's explanation that it depends on scale, complexity and various other reasons in determining the schedule.  But I think the Minister has still not directly answered the question why the building of the line cannot be hastened. I hope the Minister will  answer that question.  My second point is whether the Ministry will also take into account when it constructs the MRT line, how to also ensure connectivity to the other transport contact points, ie, the buses and other public transport amenities, because this is always a perennial problem, that the lines are built but there is not much connection to the other public transport systems.
